question: The Gulf that separates Finland and Sweden is
hints: Northernmost arm of the Baltic Sea
In the south of the gulf lie the Aland Islands, between the Sea of Aland and the Archipelago Sea.
aboutAnswer:
The Gulf of Bothnia is the northernmost arm of the Baltic Sea. It is situated between Finland's west coast and Sweden's east coast.
In the south of the gulf lie the Aland Islands, between the Sea of Aland and the Archipelago Sea.
The depth and surface area of the Gulf of Bothnia are constantly decreasing, as the land is rising after it had been pressed down by the continental ice during last ice age. The rise is 80 cm every hundred years.
Being nearly fresh, the gulf is frozen over five months every year. The icing of the Baltic Sea begins and ends in the northern Gulf of Bothnia. Traffic restrictions for icebreaker assistance are typically in force for all the gulf from late January to late April and for the northernmost ports from the middle of December to the middle of May.
